case test that) or it can be eliminated. There's no reason you

voke a method directly to test it.


It's still better if you do.  It's eas=
ier to locate an error if the method
that caused it is directly above it on=
 the stack trace rather than if you
have three potential culprits.

Here is=
 a quick example:  I once presented a list in a certain order in
HTML, and =
this order suddenly started being wrong.  I traced this error all
the way d=
own to the sorting routine, which was private and not tested.  If I
had a u=
nit test for that private method, I would have been able to pinpoint
the pr=
oblem right away instead of wasting my time in the code that generates
the =
HTML.

Back to the original question.  You have two options:

   - You abso=
lutely want to keep that method private, and in this case,
   you should pr=
obably invoke it via reflection (see setAccessible(true)).

   - You can re=
lax the visibility of this method, in which case I suggest
   making it pac=
kage protected and then put your test in the same package (it
   can still =
be in a separate source folder).

I recommend the latter approach...
